intro: Tapinanthus thorei, commonly known as the parasitic morning glory, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the roots of other plants to obtain water and nutrients. It belongs to the family Convolvulaceae, which includes many flowering plants with trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant is native to Africa and is characterized by its vine-like growth habit and striking, showy flowers. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. Due to its parasitic nature, it can negatively impact the growth of its host plants.
